utterances: You're listening to TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
And let's see if we get a listener involved in the conversation.
Jeff Williams joins us from Nashville, Tennessee.
I was just listening to NPR and they started talking about the Living in the Circle band and June Carter Cash.
Well, it's great to talk to you.
I just got a message from you earlier.
I wanted to know on the record, and this is, I guess, an official interview…
…did your mom really write ""Ring of Fire"" or did your dad write ""Ring of Fire""?
My mother wrote ""Ring of Fire."" And now…
The musical treatment that was his inclusion.
And also I think he might have changed the lyric here or there, because it was into the dusty pyre at one point, which was my mother's original lyric.
But it was - melody, spirit and pen - it was my mother and Merle Kilgore.
Well, for those who may have been trapped in a cave for the first 50 years, let's hear a little bite of ""Ring of Fire.
(Singing) Love is a burning thing and it makes a fiery ring.
Bound by wild desire, I fell into a ring of fire.
I'm embarrassed I turned that down, but we want to get on with the conversation.
And so, yeah, that's a big voice to fade.
Nevertheless, we think of that song, and just going onto Jeff's question, as your dad's song.
She did early on as a demo back in the 1960s.
And then in her next to last released record that was - actually won a Grammy, the record ""Press On,"" she recorded it.
So, yeah, it was on ""Press On."" And she has a beautiful version of it.
I just produced also a tribute CD to her music.
The Costello, the one with the glasses.
So that's out there, ""Anchored in Love"" is the title of it also.
Jeff Williams, thanks very much for the call.
And one thing, if you want to hear the new John and June for the new millennium you need to check out Texarkana Duet(ph).
Let's see if we can get another caller.
Bernard's with us from North Branch in Michigan.
Yes, in the heart of the thumb, in the state of Michigan.
I just have a question in regards to a lot of the unreleased material that June Carter had written and recorded over the years.
I've hit I don't know how many Web sites that have indicated that there are somewhere in the area of, you know, a few hundred songs that have been unreleased, however, recorded, you know.
I'm not going to give advertisements to any other artists, but, you know, with my understanding that it would be very close to another artist from Minneapolis and one from New Jersey.
And I was curious if there was going to be plans to release that and like a catalogue tracing back to the Carter family, or like unreleased B-Sides(ph) et cetera.
Are we talking about Prince and Bon Jovi here?
Maybe Bob Dylan and Bruce Springsteen.
Are you talking about June Carter released - unreleased material?
Well, you know, best of luck on your book and, you know, I look forward to reading the same…
Now I say, that there's not.
But, I mean, there maybe something in the, you know, the Columbia vaults, because she did a record for them back in the day, you know, back in the '60s.

But she - actually, you can go to dealsonrecords.com(ph) and you can get ""The Best of June Carter Cash,"" which has three songs on it that weren't on either ""Press On"" or ""Wildwood Flower,"" which were her last two records.
And those three songs that I know of were the last unreleased June Carter material.
Well, I appreciate you taking the time taking my call.
And I'm taking my call and comment off the air.
